1470011804092801028.name: Understanding Animal Research
1470011804092801028.tweet: Brain imaging of four octopus species has revealed that diurnal species in shallow reefs have complex brains with more folds, but nocturnal or deep-sea octopus have less complex, smoother brains #AnimalResearch    https://t.co/zwxwvUkh5y  https://t.co/qJXndLRfXR

1468955466453508099.name: The Cephalopod Citizen Science Project
1468955466453508099.tweet: Octopuses change their skin texture using papillae, which you can see clearly in this photo. Papillae are structures in the skin that can change shape and size. They are surrounded by muscles which control any changes in appearance.  üì∑ Danel Wentzel  https://t.co/djdLUaQzCR

1467417305327947779.name: Just Science it
1467417305327947779.tweet: An Octopus in a Hurry  The Coconut Octopus üêô (Amphioctopus Marginatus) is one of only two octopus species that engages in bipedal locomotion, a behavior that lets them move quickly over the ocean floor while looking like a tumbling coconut to potential predators above.  https://t.co/18BY5AW1V4
